PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: A. L. K. H.
Address: Regina
Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1900-1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? South Bluff, near Humboldt
Where had you been living before that? Weyburn
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? At least 30 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice or three times yearly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Made in Canada
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $5.00
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Prince Albert
How far away? 27.5 miles What year? 1906-1904
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use? Red Wheat
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it?

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Christmas dinner was the night before, supper, or Christmas dinner itself. We had fish for dinner, fish for supper.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Christmas dinner was the night before, supper, or Christmas dinner itself. We had fish for dinner, fish for supper.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always kept prepared for anything that might happen. We always started to prepare for winter in early October, having on hand at least 5000 fish mostly white fish. Fish, ducks, geese and game were always hung up on poles so the animals could not steal them. This fish was intended for our dogs as we had six good sleigh dogs to look after, also we always tried to have at least one net, about 20 yards of mesh in the water for our supply of fish for our dogs, the dogs were very important.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The simplest form of cooking applied to all meals so long as we had a supply of salt; when the water running short, we could mix in a burning tea-bag or lantern in place of salt and use appearance to ordinary tea for seasoning them in the last bath which is collected.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In the earlier years up to about 1904 flour was brought in from Winnipeg via Grand Rapids and from there by flatboat to the different northern posts. I do not think the quantity would be more than 25 lbs per individual per year, later when transportation changed from Prince Albert, larger quantities of flour were transported by canoe down the river to Cumberland and distributed from there, also from Prince Albert by horse sleighs to Montreal Lake and again from there by flat sleighs drawn by single horses to La Ronge and to nearby missions, a horse sleigh load would be 8-950 lbs each of flour, and fed for three previous to this the missionaries at Stanley cultivated a small plot of land, about two acres where they grew...
